column2: Eager to see jd  movie
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: No one has the right to shelve a movie, about something as important as mercury poisoning to an entire race of people. This is something the world needs to know about. It’s not just a movie! It’s a documentary! MGM has no right to deny Canada, & the US from seeing it. They’re afraid Johnny Depp will make money on the movie. Johnny Depp doesn’t care about the money. That was not why he wanted to make it! He felt we had a right to know! And, I stand beside him! We do have the right to know! Change can’t happen if no one knows the story!

column2:
‘Minamata’ deserves to be seen!
Purchasing the US distribution rights to Andrew Levitas’ film ‘Minamata’ then refusing to release said film is unconscionable.
No longer MGM the giant of the lion’s roar; now mgm a small paper tiger, poof!
MGM Studios: Stand up for ‘Minamata’, release it, and support it properly as you contractually agreed to do. Glory or shame are your choices. Go big. Choose the path of glory: Release ‘Minamata’!

column2: This story is too important not to be told!
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: This is an important movie that needs to be seen, the people of Minamata deserve to be heard and seen. Johnny Depp has made the film with the humanity only he can instill and that film is receiving worldwide acclaim from critics and consumers aiike.  That MGM and WB would shelve this film and set themselves up as gatekeepers of censorship for all of North America is just entirely too much.  If you want to continue to support Husband abuser, Amber Heard fine, but at least be fair and stop your obsessive cancelling of her victim. the evidence is stacked strongly in his favor of being completely innocent, and her evidence is now being outed as being manufactured and lacking any substance. #ReleaseMinamata #JuticeForJohnnyDepp
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: This movie is too important to be shelved because of some fear of going against "a woman."  Heard lied through her teeth, and people who have lost loved ones to a terrible disease are suffering for it.  The movie that exposes all that happened to their loved ones that would give them closure has been shelved because of one actor who was persecuted for something he did not do.  The movie needs to be released.  It's too important not to be.

column2: Regardless of how people feel about Johnny Depp, this is a movie that must be shown. This is an awareness that must be shown. Personally I feel that this attack on Johnny Depp is disgusting.

column2: I’m signing for two important reasons. Firstly because I’m tired of the pointless garbage being put out by studios. This is a movie about something that actually matters. Secondly, I find it so dishonourable that studios would bury an important movie in order to punish someone falsely accused. Take the time to actually listen to the full audio tapes and you would know who the villain actually is. #justiceforjohnny

column2: This movie is very important for the victims of the Minamata disease. Attempitng to not promoting it is a huge mistake. And Johnny Depp deserves to recognized for his work. Everyone knows that Johnny Depp is innocenr and deserves better. He deserves the whole world. #JusticeforJohnnyDepp
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: For the distributor (that’s all they are) to decide that possible backlash against them is more important than releasing a film that speaks for the victims of this disaster is disgusting. The film and Johnny Depp have been receiving awards worldwide with no backlash so their concern is unfounded. It is a weak excuse for their obvious bigotry.
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. column2: MGM please release this film! The film is about an important history of mercury pollution in Japan in 1954-1964 and well documented by Eugene Smith and his wife Aileen Smith. The same pollution are still happening all over the world done by irresponsible corporations and greedy people. This film is an important part of a global campaign on mercury pollution and support the Minamata Convention on mercury. Currently, the Minamata Convention already ratified by 132 countries. In fact, the struggles and fight for justice of the Minamata victims continues until today!

The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: Release Minamata
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

column2:
Eu apoio porquê, amo este gigante ator. Quero muito assistir este filme porque foi feito com dedicação de vários profissionais mostrando uma história verídica.
Essa história precisa ser mostrada ao mundo todo.
Muito me admiro USA, um País tão culto, ainda cometer esse tipo de atitude!
Xô preconceito!
Respeite todos os profissionais deste filme. Essa pegação de pé, com Johnny Deep já está ficando feio!
Deixem esse gigante ator, produtor, músico, pintor etc.. seguir sua vida em paz! �
#Minamata deve prosseguir seu percurso. �❤️

column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: This movie Minamata deserves to be seen here in the USA
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. column2: Apoyo total a Jhonny Deep
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2:
MGM are suppressing a film because their parent company has a problem with the star of the film. This is bs. The subject matter deserves to be seen far and wide. Any problems WB have with JD (who they have treated appallingly, and continue to do so) should not be carried over to this film. 
It's not as though WB /MGM can afford to suppress a film that will be very profitable, they are deeply financially compromised and this stance will only make it worse. Customers will vote with their feet and their wallets. Ignore them at your peril
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: I WANT TO SEE THIS MOVIE IN A THEATER.  NOW!!!
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: Minamata it's a true story and it needs to be known to the whole world! JohnnyDepp is abused from all sides, I never understand why, even those in his native country, do not want this film, which has very good reviews where it was seen, I have seen the film and I recommend it to everyone. I congratulate the whole team of professionals who made a movie about a true story, masterfully! By far, I find the best compositional role of our handsome Johnny Depp Star! The right to work and to harness work is a legal right, for all people, so let the film run in the U.S., has nothing to do with his trial at court with his ex wife, with the movie Minamata!! Johnny Depp is not an abuser, we fans claim he was abused with the evidence given to the press "by mistake" by ex!!! God bless you Johnny Depp!!!

The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: There is no valid reason that this story shouldn't be told. No excuse is good enough. Release the film so millions who support this work can view it. Let the public decide who/what to support.
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. Please don’t victimize him anymore than what he has already been through! My heart goes out to him.

column2: I am from Russia, we had this film at the box office, and I watched it 5 times! And I want to be able to watch it both in America and around the world, coming to the cinemas of their city. Moreover, this film MUST be watched because it touches on social issues. Ecology is a global problem for which there are no state borders. The film does not leave you indifferent. And to justify not releasing the film by the personal problems of Johnny Depp (who perfectly played the photographer Eugene Smith) is silly. Firstly, because he is innocent, secondly, the artistic value of the film is much higher, and thirdly, many people watch movies, but are not interested in the personal lives of the actors. And you can't deprive them of the opportunity to watch the movie.

column2: RELEASE THE MOVIE. JUSTICE FOR JOHNNY DEPP
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. column2:
I was looking forward to the February release date in the US but every movie theater I looked up for tickets did not show any signs the movie would be playing there.

It is a shame that the studios, especially Warner Bros & MGM would deny people and descendants of the tragedy to see the story come to life because the studios want to punish Johnny Depp; who has never been charged or found guilty of domestic abuse and if anything, so far has submitted official proof to show he was the abused and their is nothing to date proving he is the abuser.

The studios should be ashamed of themselves for backing an self proclaimed abuser & shelving the work that so many put their heart & soul into getting this film created.

Stop the bullshit & release the film; they're only making themselves look bad. Our family will not pay to see any WB or MGM productions again if they refuse to do the right thing.

column2: Regardless of what they may feel for Johnny Depp, are they willing to dismiss and write off all of these victims? Plus, at the rate others are loosing money for turning their back on him and others are gaining a ridiculous amount of it for their support, backing Depp means you can probably afford to buy your competition. Oh, and it's just all around the right thing to do.
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column2: The victims deserve their voices to be heard. Johnny depp is a legend, a beautiful soul, a gentle and a gentleman , he will lend a very positive outcome for the film. He is a abuse survivor and he does not deserve any of the treatment he is getting!

column2: There is no logical reason to hold this movie back. The message in it is powerful and there are people in the world that are still suffering from this deadly disease and the message should be told. There is a mountain of evidence to prove that he is innocent of any domestic abuse of anybody. In Johnny's case the victim is being treated like he is guilty and the guilty is being treated like she is innocent. This is not right and a slap in the face to all victims of abuse. Amber tried to ruin Johnny and MGM is not helping the situation. This story should be told and an innocent man should be able to continue to do what he loves to do.

column2: I’ve been looking forward to this for a long time, but we can’t see it because of petty political issues in the USA that have nothing to do with the film. Stop treating us Asians like a sideshow piece, and let our tragedies be heard so the world can learn!

column2:
This is an important movie based on true events ... it can bring awareness re: harmful effects of big industry focused on profits rather than the environment & the well being of humanity (still occurring all around the world to this day) ... Not to mention the fact that the big business studio is only suppressing it because of the personal life of one actor ... & more & more evidence supports the fact that this actor has been falsely accused & seriously misjudged by those too overly zealous about trying to jump on the #me-too bandwagon (I have been a victim of the type assaults (more than once over my lifetime) that started the #metoo movement in the first place ... & someone like the female accuser (in this case) falsely using it to try to gain sympathy & increase her fame is an insult to real victims ... 
Release The Movie! ...

column2: Johnny Depp is innocent, and it's not morally right to suppress a film this important. It's not right to the victims of Minamata who deserve their story to be told. It's not right to Johnny Depp who has overwhelming evidence his accuser is a liar, and it's not right to the cast, crew, director of Minamata. There is literally no risk to WB/MGM of backlash because the public stands behind Depp based on actual evidence, so this is just so ridiculous it would be laughable if it weren't so messed up.

column2: Let the audience decide to see it or not!
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

Give the People who give you a career what they want.. It is guaranteed to keep your career going!

column2:
Minamata is an important film documenting the tragedy of the mercury poisoning in Japan.
Johnny Depp is a superb actor with a heart of pure gold and apparently he is oscar-worthy in this film.
Nobody should ‘bury’ such an important work, least of all because the best actor of our time is being wrongly bullied by the media.
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

Until this film is released in the US my wallet remains closed to all things MGM. #releaseMinamataintheUS #justiceforMinamata #JusticeForJohnnyDepp
column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

About the victims whom story is depicted in the movie:

Minamata disease was first discovered in the city of Minamata, Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, in 1956. It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. While cat, dog, pig, and human deaths continued for 36 years, Chisso and the Kumamoto prefectural government did little to prevent the epidemic, and even went as far as to try and bury it, much like MGM is for the time being attempting to do with this film. As of March 2001, 2,265 victims had been officially recognised as having Minamata disease (1,784 of whom had died)

You can read more about the situation with MGM here:

https://www.indiewire.com/2021/07/minamata-director-accuses-mgm-burying-film-johnny-depp-1234653673/


Not only is the public outraged by this, but they are banding together to push MGM to release the film with “#ReleaseMinamataMovie” which is currently trending on Twitter alongside “#JusticeForJohnnyDepp”. The people want to see this movie, and a large portion of the reason being that they want to support Johnny Depp, as it is now widely known that he is a victim of Domestic Abuse at the hands of his ex-wife, Amber Heard. 

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences. 

MGM: Read the room, and realize that the people want this movie released. This goes far beyond Johnny Depp and his trials over the last few years. If you were unaware, there is a Change Petition to “Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2” that’s garnered over 2 million signatures (and counting) Not to mention the success, support, and gratitude from the public for Dior, who has chosen to stand firmly with Johnny Depp for the sale of their cologne “Sauvage” which broke records in it’s sales. Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite. 

We stand with Johnny Depp, and we stand with the victims and survivors of Minamata, and we hope this petition serves to prove to you, MGM, that we WANT the release of Minamata.

The people refuse to stand by silently as Johnny Depp is yet again treated wrongfully (for things there is more than enough evidence readily available to prove that he did not do) with extreme bias by the morally corrupt and biased media, and Hollywood. Even putting Johnny Depp aside for one moment, MGM is clearly ignoring the weight of awareness this film carries, and that withholding Minamata’s release is depriving thousands of victims their voice, and their experiences.

Negative backlash from the public is an unreasonable fear, as your releasing the movie will surely result in the exact opposite.

column52:
MGM is attempting to bury the Minamata Movie, which brings awareness to the thousands of people that were affected by the Minamata disease (some of whom who are still suffering to this day) because actor Johnny Depp is the lead actor in the movie, and their excuse is that they are afraid that having him in the movie will result in negative backlash.

It was caused by the release of methylmercury in the industrial wastewater from a chemical factory owned by the Chisso Corporation, which continued from 1932 to 1968. It has also been suggested that some of the mercury sulfate in the wastewater was also metabolized to methylmercury by bacteria in the sediment. This highly toxic chemical bioaccumulated and biomagnified in shellfish and fish in Minamata Bay and the Shiranui Sea, which, when eaten by the local population, resulted in mercury poisoning and widespread death and suffering. column2:
This important movie needs to be released now!!! 
Stop punishing Mr Depp. He is obviously the victim & not the abuser. My siblings & I are survivors of physical & mental abuse by step father & my brother suffered the same by his ex wife. The abuse issue is extremely important to us. 
You make it harder for REAL VICTIMS to come forward when you reward the abuser & disbelieve & punish the victim.
